Introduction
This article contains a collection of content written for the One-Minute Telegram, a biweekly newsletter that presents the newest medical research condensed into just one minute of reading. This newsletter is designed for all of our colleagues who want to stay current on the latest medical literature without having to comb through and dissect medical studies themselves. It is peer-reviewed by our team of physician editors and integrated into the
[Amboss](/de/wissen/Ohr#Z2e6489810ab8a5524d8534501fcab9be) library. Even after a long night shift or a busy day on the wards, it should go down easy. Sign up via the link in “Tips and Links” below.
See also our
[One-Minute Telegram Archiv 2021](/de/wissen/One-Minute_Telegram_Archiv_2021#Zedc2f5a9b0e39469c09137ff9a4dcb1e) and [One-Minute Telegram Archiv 2020](/de/wissen/One-Minute_Telegram_Archiv_2020#Ze765573a3b5d8aa28f098b044fb31e6e).

Edition 65 - December 17, 2022
2022 U.S. Preventive Services Task Force: summary of recommendations
One-Minute Telegram 65-2022-1/3: Happy holidays! The AMBOSS team is here to share some of the most relevant updates to the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendations this holiday season. A searchable overview of the recommendations can be found here. [1]
- Primary prevention
- Statins for primary
[atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)( [ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)) prevention [2][3]
- USPSTF continues to recommend statins for adults aged 40–75 years with an estimated
[ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)risk of ≥ 10%; shared decision-making is recommended for adults with lower risk (7.5% to < 10%). [4]
- Benefits and risks of primary prevention for adults aged < 40 years and those > 75 years remain uncertain.
- USPSTF continues to recommend statins for adults aged 40–75 years with an estimated
- Dietary supplements to prevent
[ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)and cancer [5][6]
- USPSTF reaffirms its 2014 recommendations against the use of beta carotene and
[vitamin E](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Zcc3966fa2cc78ee4586d724bcc14e03d)supplements.
- Evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against other dietary supplements.
- USPSTF reaffirms its 2014 recommendations against the use of beta carotene and

[Aspirin](/de/wissen/Thrombozytenaggregationshemmer#Z2bf6095ed24962e2237f2691a98fca66)use for primary prevention of [ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)and colorectal cancer [7][8]
- USPSTF recommends against starting low-dose
[aspirin](/de/wissen/Thrombozytenaggregationshemmer#Z2bf6095ed24962e2237f2691a98fca66)for primary prevention of [ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)in adults aged ≥ 60 years.
- Based on evidence of a small net benefit, daily low-dose
[aspirin](/de/wissen/Thrombozytenaggregationshemmer#Z2bf6095ed24962e2237f2691a98fca66)may be considered on an individual basis in adults aged 40–59 years with a 10-year [ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)risk of ≥ 10% and a low risk of bleeding.
- Whether low-dose
[aspirin](/de/wissen/Thrombozytenaggregationshemmer#Z2bf6095ed24962e2237f2691a98fca66)reduces the risk of colorectal cancer remains unclear.
- USPSTF recommends against starting low-dose
-

- In
[postmenopausal](/de/wissen/Klimakterium#Zac4b020fde98661beb72a24ef0b8c067)persons, the USPSTF recommends against using [estrogen](/de/wissen/Sexualhormone#Z3125e0c64f510742be94df34078cd5d7)and progestin combinations for primary prevention of chronic conditions.

-

Evidence-based prevention is the best medicine!

Better outcomes with alternative
[defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7) strategies
One-Minute Telegram 65-2022-2/3
- Background: Ventricular
[fibrillation](VF) is often refractory to initial [defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7)attempts. [17] Modifications to [defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7)techniques may lead to earlier successful [defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7)and better outcomes. This study compared standard [defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7)vs. double sequential external [defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7)(DSED) or vector-change (VC) [defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7)in out-of-hospital refractory VF.
- Study population
- 405 adults with refractory VF (i.e., persistent VF after delivery of three consecutive shocks)
- Mean age 63.6 years, 84.4% male
- Methods: cluster randomized controlled trial
- Three intervention groups
- Standard
[defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7): [defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7)pads in anterior and lateral positions (n = 136)
- VC
[defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7): [defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7)pads in anterior and posterior positions (n = 144)
- DSED: rapid sequential shocks from two defibrillators (n = 125)
- Standard
- Primary outcome: survival to hospital discharge
- Secondary outcomes included:
- Termination of VF
[Return of spontaneous circulation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z56dd86d31686ff69493223c49fc7e4c6)
- Good neurologic outcome
- Three intervention groups
- Main results
- Survival to hospital discharge
- Standard group: 13.3%
- VC group: 21.7% (RR vs. standard, 1.71; 95% CI, 1.01–2.88)
- DSED group: 30.4% (RR vs. standard, 2.21; 1.33–3.67)
- Compared to the standard group, all secondary outcomes occurred more frequently in the DSED group; termination of VF also occurred more frequently in the VC group.
- Survival to hospital discharge
- Limitations include:
- Trial stopped before the planned sample size was achieved due to
[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7)-related logistical challenges.
- Small number of primary outcome events may overestimate treatment effect.
- Lack of follow-up after hospital discharge
- Trial stopped before the planned sample size was achieved due to
The take-home message?
In this trial, patients who received DSED for refractory VF in out-of-hospital settings had improved survival and neurologic outcomes compared to those who received standard
[defibrillation](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Reanimation#Z80fec1741f2c473afd7e79f3850c01c7). Further studies are needed to assess if these results are reproducible and applicable to other treatment settings.

Misunderstanding of medical jargon in the general population
One-Minute Telegram 65-2022-3/3
- Background: Health care workers frequently use technical terms and medical jargon while communicating with patients. This study assessed the understanding of common medical phrases among members of the general public.
- Study population: 215 English-speaking adults with no medical training (mean age 42 years, 63% female)
- Methods: cross-sectional study
- Participants were randomized to a written or verbal 13-question survey including multiple-choice and open-ended questions about frequently used medical jargon.
- Responses were collected at the 2021 Minnesota State Fair.
- Main results
- Understood terms for good news
- Negative cancer screening: 96.3%
- Negative blood culture: 86.5%
- Unremarkable chest x-ray: 79.5%
- Understood terms for bad news
-
[Tumor](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Onkologie#Z96dbcb525ee590dbfa7e193aeb93cb24)is progressing: 79.1%
- Positive nodes: 66.5%
- Febrile: 9.3%
- Bugs in urine: 28.8%
-
- Understanding of jargon vs. nonjargon
- Blood culture was negative (86.5%) vs. blood culture showed no infection (96.7%); P < 0.001
- NPO (11.2%) vs. nothing by mouth (75.3%); P < 0.001
- Understood terms for good news
- Limitations include:
-
[Selection bias](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Zb0d0a6354852d24efe462b33bd4690de): Participants were visitors to a university research building, which also had a mask mandate.
- Generalizability: Participants had above-average education levels.
- Multiple-choice questions may have made answers easier to guess.
-
The take-home message?
These survey results suggest that common medical jargon may often be poorly understood by the general public. Health care workers should be trained to avoid medical jargon when communicating with patients.

[Asymmetrische Kommunikation](/de/wissen/Arzt-Patient-Beziehung#Z7566eec9f8d0ee04b7494fddfdf78e42)| [Untersuchung und Gespräch](/de/wissen/Untersuchung_und_Gespräch#Z1f3539196e38cec918c8e608227e5627)
- Original study: Accuracy in patient understanding of common medical phrases [19]
- Authors: Gotlieb R et al.
- Journal: JAMA Netw Open
- Study funding: NIH National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences; University of Minnesota
Edition 64 - December 03, 2022
Crossword puzzles beat cognitive games
One-Minute Telegram 64-2022-1/3
- Background: Complex mental activity has been shown to reduce the risk of dementia [20] and improve everyday function [21] in older adults, but studies on individuals with preexisting mild cognitive impairment (MCI) are scarce. This study sought to examine the effect of cognitive training with web-based cognitive games versus web-based crossword puzzles on cognition and functional performance in older adults with MCI.
- Study population: 107 patients with MCI (mean age 71.2 years, 58% female)
- Methods: two-site, single-blinded, randomized treatment trial
- Intervention: patients randomized 1:1 to train with crossword puzzles (n = 51) or cognitive games (n = 56)
- Primary outcome: change in cognitive performance from
[baseline](/de/wissen/Kardiotokografie_(CTG)#Z2e7e2d1776c1d22f8722ebdfa4ddd293)to week 78 (measured using ADAS-Cog score [22]; range from 0 to 70; higher scores indicate greater cognitive impairment)
- Secondary outcomes
- Change in functional performance (measured using UPSA scores [23]) and/or impairment in instrumental activities of daily living (measured using FAQ scores [24])
- Change in hippocampal volume and cortical thickness on MRI
- Main results
- Significant difference in ADAS-Cog score between groups
- Mean scores worsened with games (mean +0.4 points; from 9.53 to 9.93) and improved with crosswords (mean -1 point; from 9.59 to 8.61).
- Improvement of ≥ 2 points: seen in 25% of participants in the games group vs. 37.3% in the crosswords group
- FAQ score worsened more in the games than in the crosswords group; there were no differences in UPSA scores.
- MRI: greater decrease in hippocampal volume and cortical thickness in the games group
- Limitations include:
- Uncertain clinical relevance of small ADAS-Cog score changes in patients with MCI
-
[Absence](/de/wissen/Epileptische_Anfälle_und_Epilepsien#Z93dedd171a6efaddb5d27c931860ee21)of a control group: The effect of crossword puzzles compared to no cognitive training was not assessed.
- Limited generalizability: On average, participants had high education levels.
The take-home message?
In this trial of patients with MCI, at 78 weeks, crossword puzzle training was associated with improved mean cognition scores, while cognitive game training was associated with worsened cognition scores. However, the implications of these results for clinical practice remain uncertain. Further studies are needed to assess whether game-based cognitive training has any significant effect on the progression of MCI compared to no training.
- AMBOSS links:
[Übersicht Geriatrie](/de/wissen/Übersicht_Geriatrie#Z1184db8a6ce52feb7970e8cbc965742e)| [Demenz](/de/wissen/Demenz#Z550bcfc577560faea37bbddda0e01e7b)| [Morbus Alzheimer](/de/wissen/Morbus_Alzheimer#Z355d10c7e7f39ad060b2a6c28268f874)
- Original study: Computerized games versus crosswords training in mild cognitive impairment [25]
- Authors: Devanand DP et al.
- Journal: NEJM Evidence
- Study funding: National Institute on Aging
New weapon in the fight against
[malaria](/de/wissen/Malaria#Zbf5a231c10fbf07ba7c213e2dd494d1f)
One-Minute Telegram 64-2022-2/3
- Background: There were an estimated 627,000
[malaria](/de/wissen/Malaria#Zbf5a231c10fbf07ba7c213e2dd494d1f)deaths [26] in 2020 despite a wide variety of preventive strategies and treatment options. Efforts to decrease the [malaria](/de/wissen/Malaria#Zbf5a231c10fbf07ba7c213e2dd494d1f)mortality rate have stalled and the development of a vaccine [27] is progressing slowly. This study sought to determine the safety and [efficacy](/de/wissen/Patientenversorgung_und_Gesundheitssystem#Z9c24089e9b15284c931c20e196ceb36f)of a single prophylactic monoclonal antibody (CIS43LS) [infusion](/de/wissen/Flüssigkeits-_und_Volumentherapie#Z0bcf219f7dd2c28bf4e24b8581e76e81)against [Plasmodium falciparum](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Parasitologie#Z800da2c0c51c6f64339721abecbdf95a)infection.
- Study population: healthy nonpregnant adults aged 18–55 years living in areas with endemic P. falciparum
[malaria](/de/wissen/Malaria#Zbf5a231c10fbf07ba7c213e2dd494d1f)in Mali
- Part A (safety)
- Methods: open-label, dose-escalation study in 18 participants
- Main results:
[Adverse events](/de/wissen/Qualitätsmanagement#Z4819640973dcff73dbf583f1b61eae1c)were mild-to-moderate at 24 weeks; risk of moderate headache was higher with 40 mg/kg CIS43LS compared to [placebo](risk ratio, 3.3; 95% CI, 1.1–9.7).
- Part B (
[efficacy](/de/wissen/Patientenversorgung_und_Gesundheitssystem#Z9c24089e9b15284c931c20e196ceb36f))
- Methods: double-blind, randomized,
[placebo]-controlled trial
- Main results
- Infection rate over 24 weeks: 78.2% in
[placebo]group, 35.5% in 10 mg/kg CIS43LS group, 18.2% in 40 mg/kg CIS43LS group
- Compared to
[placebo], the [efficacy](/de/wissen/Patientenversorgung_und_Gesundheitssystem#Z9c24089e9b15284c931c20e196ceb36f)of CIS43LS in preventing P. falciparum infection over a 6-month period was:
- 88.2% (95% CI, 79.3–93.3%) in the 40 mg/kg group.
- 75.0% (61.0–84.0%) in the 10 mg/kg group.
- Infection rate over 24 weeks: 78.2% in
- Methods: double-blind, randomized,
- Limitations include:
- Limited generalizability: Participants were healthy, nonpregnant adults from a single country.
- Reasons for breakthrough infections are unclear.
The take-home message?
This study demonstrated that a single dose of monoclonal antibodies was well-tolerated and provided effective protection against P. falciparum infection in healthy, nonpregnant adults during a 6-month
[malaria](/de/wissen/Malaria#Zbf5a231c10fbf07ba7c213e2dd494d1f) season in Mali. Further research on the use of monoclonal antibodies in preventing [malaria](/de/wissen/Malaria#Zbf5a231c10fbf07ba7c213e2dd494d1f) is ongoing [28], but this promising addition to the global fight against [malaria](/de/wissen/Malaria#Zbf5a231c10fbf07ba7c213e2dd494d1f) is an exciting development.

[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7)-related stress may cause menstrual irregularity
One-Minute Telegram 64-2022-3/3
- Background: Menstrual health [30] offers insight into women’s overall well-being and is affected by many factors, including high stress levels. The authors of this study investigated the hypothesis that women with high levels of
[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7)-related stress would report more changes in their menstrual parameters than women with lower stress.
- Study population: 354 women aged 18–45 years with menstrual cycles not altered by factors such as pregnancy, postpartum period (< 3 months), use of hormonal birth control, recent infertility treatment, or hysterectomy
- Methods: cross-sectional study
- Main results
-
[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7)-related stress was classified as low in 89.5% (n = 317) and high in 10.5% (n = 37).
- High
[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7)-related stress was associated with changes in cycle length (OR, 2.32; 95% CI, 1.12–4.85), period duration (2.38; 1.14–4.98), and [spotting](/de/wissen/Menstruationszyklus_und_Zyklusanomalien#Z283c4dff28dc7e7c4c5131a8a539d187)between cycles (2.32; 1.03–5.22), but not significantly associated with changes in menstrual flow (1.61; 0.77–3.34).
- Results were independent of age, education, non-
[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7)-related mental health, smoking, and weight.
-
- Limitations include:
- Potential for
[recall bias](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Z34d41b30a792b17afcdd32b43ce85f19)in participant responses
- Possible
[selection bias](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Zb0d0a6354852d24efe462b33bd4690de)with online survey
- Potential for
The take-home message?
This study demonstrated that a high level of stress attributed to the
[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7) pandemic was associated with multiple changes in the menstrual cycle. Health care providers should be aware of potential [COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7)-related stress when addressing patients’ menstrual health.

- Background: The AHA/
[ACC](/de/wissen/Medikamente_gegen_Husten_und_bronchiale_Obstruktion#Z3f6dd950678a8bcdd0077eab31629f32)recommends direct [oral]anticoagulants (DOACs) for the prevention of thromboembolism in most patients with atrial [fibrillation](AF), but which [DOAC](/de/wissen/Vitamin-K-Antagonisten_und_direkte_orale_Antikoagulanzien#Z9faede06af720d5eefc8282fbea07721)is preferred remains unclear. - Outcomes of interest: ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke, systemic embolism,
[gastrointestinal](/de/wissen/Übersicht_des_Verdauungssystems#Zaa3f0692fb4127b17e934892e975ec10)bleed (GIB), and all-cause mortality
- Main results

- No substantial difference in other outcomes of interest

- Limitations include:

- Severity of GIB was not assessed.

The take-home message?
In this large international observational study of DOACs in the management of AF,
[apixaban](/de/wissen/Vitamin-K-Antagonisten_und_direkte_orale_Antikoagulanzien#Zfb1cda072cc01083f54cf4994cb89911) was associated with a similar risk of stroke and systemic embolism as other commonly used DOACs, but with a lower risk of GIB. These results point to a preference for [apixaban](/de/wissen/Vitamin-K-Antagonisten_und_direkte_orale_Antikoagulanzien#Zfb1cda072cc01083f54cf4994cb89911) for the prevention of thromboembolism in the management of AF, but risks and benefits should be considered individually for each patient.

The interval between hemodialysis and surgery matters
One-Minute Telegram 63-2022-2/3
- Background: Patients with end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) on chronic hemodialysis (HD) have an elevated risk for postoperative complications, but high-quality evidence on the optimal timing of dialysis prior to surgery is lacking. The goal of this study was to assess whether a longer interval between HD and elective surgery is associated with higher postoperative mortality. [35]
- Study population: 1,147,846 elective surgical procedures in 346,828 Medicare fee-for-service-insured adults (
[median](/de/wissen/Angewandte_Statistik#Z7c0546fc00695bf5211ab50534e91c9b)age 65 years; 43% female) on long-term HD
- Methods: retrospective cohort study
- Data obtained from a US national database of patients on HD
- Exposures:
- Number of days between last outpatient HD and surgical procedure
- HD vs. no HD on day of surgery
- Outcome: 90-day postoperative mortality
- Main results
- Longer intervals between HD and surgery were associated with a higher absolute risk of 90-day mortality.
- 2 days vs. 1 day: 4.7% vs. 4.2%; adjusted HR, 1.14 (95% CI, 1.10–1.18)
- 3 days vs. 1 day: 5.2% vs. 4.2%; adjusted HR, 1.25 (1.19–1.31)
- 3 days vs. 2 days: 5.2% vs. 4.7%; adjusted HR, 1.09 (1.04–1.13)
- HD on the day of surgery was associated with a lower risk of 90-day mortality: 4.0% vs. 4.5%; adjusted HR, 0.88 (95% CI, 0.84–0.91)
- Longer intervals between HD and surgery were associated with a higher absolute risk of 90-day mortality.
- Limitations include:
- Findings not generalizable to emergency surgery
- Potential for residual
[confounding](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Zb4262971e106e4799561831435f78cd1)given the observational study design
The take-home message?
This study suggests that a shorter interval between HD and surgery decreases the risk of postoperative mortality. Since the absolute risk differences associated with different time intervals were small and subject to residual
[confounding](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Zb4262971e106e4799561831435f78cd1), prospective studies are warranted.

The aim of this study was to compare the risk of major or clinically relevant non-major bleeding (CRNMB) between [apixaban](/de/wissen/Vitamin-K-Antagonisten_und_direkte_orale_Antikoagulanzien#Zfb1cda072cc01083f54cf4994cb89911)and [warfarin](/de/wissen/Vitamin-K-Antagonisten_und_direkte_orale_Antikoagulanzien#Z7d350957bfc20f511eb53f8d589b8adc)in patients with AF and ESKD on hemodialysis (HD). - Methods: prospective, randomized, open-label, blinded-outcome evaluation
- Main results
- Limitations include:
The take-home message?
No conclusions on the preferred approach to stroke and thromboembolism prevention in patients with ESKD and AF can be drawn from this study. While patients who received
[apixaban](/de/wissen/Vitamin-K-Antagonisten_und_direkte_orale_Antikoagulanzien#Zfb1cda072cc01083f54cf4994cb89911) had higher rates of clinically significant bleeding than those who received [warfarin](/de/wissen/Vitamin-K-Antagonisten_und_direkte_orale_Antikoagulanzien#Z7d350957bfc20f511eb53f8d589b8adc), results should be interpreted with caution due to major study limitations. - Background: Many countries recommend screening adults (e.g., at age 45–75 years per USPSTF recommendations) [44] for colorectal cancer (

This study set out to investigate the impact of an invitation to receive a screening colonoscopy vs. no intervention on the rate of [CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7)and [CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7)-related death in countries that had no prior organized [CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7)screening programs.
- Study population: healthy adults aged 55–64 years (n = 84,585) from Norway, Sweden, and Poland with no prior
[CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7)screening
- Methods: pragmatic randomized controlled trial

- 42% of the invited group underwent screening colonoscopy
- Compared to the control group, the invitation group had (
[intention-to-treat](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Z12db0a61af1774ca03f632559492fe19)analysis):
- However, an adjusted per-protocol analysis suggested that had all invited participants undergone a colonoscopy, both
[CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7)and [CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7)-related deaths would have been significantly reduced.

The take-home message?
This study showed that a single invitation to a screening colonoscopy resulted in low colonoscopy rates, had only a modest effect on the risk of

However, the results of this study should not be overgeneralized as pragmatic US screening programs with higher colonoscopy uptake rates have demonstrated significant reduction in [CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7) and [CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7)-related death. Edition 61 - October 22, 2022
Restock your
[aspirin](/de/wissen/Thrombozytenaggregationshemmer#Z2bf6095ed24962e2237f2691a98fca66) and laceration repair kits - it’s almost Halloween!
One-Minute Telegram 61-2022-1/3
- Candy crush(ing chest pain) – Sugar crashes and hangovers may be common adverse effects of Halloween-related overindulgence, but what about myocardial infarction (MI)? This time-stratified case-crossover study [48] of patients with MI in Quebec, Canada, set out to determine if the
[odds](/de/wissen/Epidemiologie_und_Wahrscheinlichkeiten#Z12841ac5900343a9f0d2dffc6438260c)of having an MI were higher on November 1st (the day after Halloween) than on control days. The analysis demonstrated that MIs were more likely to occur the day after Halloween (OR, 1.13; 95% CI, 1.07–1.20). Post-Halloween MIs were most common in men and individuals aged 65–84 years. The study was not designed to establish causality (e.g., candy corn overdose vs. yelling at the kids to stay off the lawn).
- More gore than you were asking for – Crafting the spookiest jack-o’-lantern is a joyful Halloween tradition and may also increase the likelihood of roasting and consuming delicious pepitas. However, slippery fingers from slimy pumpkin guts can lead to serious gourd-carving cuts. This study used the National Electronic Injury Surveillance System to investigate all pumpkin-related knife injuries (PRKIs) [49] between 2012 and 2021. There were nearly 21,000 PRKIs recorded, most of which were
[hand](/de/wissen/Hand#Zbec311d267e59b3560e01b78c0e2b870)lacerations. PRKIs occurred primarily in October (83.5% of cases), with nearly half of the overall cases reported on the week of Halloween. Children aged 10–19 years were most commonly afflicted, followed by children aged < 10 years.
- Don’t blame it on the moonlight - While many doctors love to blame the full moon for an overcapacity emergency department, increased admissions, bad call nights, and werewolf attacks, many of these notions have been debunked in the scientific literature. [50] But what about seizures? This retrospective study explored whether there was a relationship between the timing of a first-ever seizure and the lunar cycle. [51] Alas, among 1710 patients with first-ever seizures, onset was evenly distributed across all lunar phases.
The take-home message?
This Halloween, remind your grandpa to go easy on the candy, don’t let children play with knives, and EDs: prep your laceration repair kits, but don’t worry about a full moon!

Edition 60 - October 8th, 2022
Real-time prescription price transparency reduces costs for patients
One-Minute Telegram 60-2022-1/3
- Background: Many providers do not accurately estimate the true out-of-pocket medication costs paid by their patients, and drug costs are a significant factor for medication nonadherence in patients with chronic disease. [59][60] This study set out to assess the patient cost-savings generated through use of a real-time prescription benefit (RTPB) system that recommended lower cost alternatives for prescriptions in the ambulatory setting.
- Study population: adults receiving outpatient prescriptions in a large, urban, academic health-care system in the US
- Methods
- Cluster randomized trial of 255 practices
- Medical practices randomized to either:
- No recommendations (control)
- RTPB system (intervention): recommendations given if an alternative medication, different pharmacy, and/or a larger supply (e.g., 90 vs. 30 days) enabled cost-savings
- Main results
- Mean out-of-pocket drug costs for 30-day prescriptions were significantly lower for the intervention group compared to the control group ($39.90 vs. $67.80; adjusted effect estimate, -11.2%; 95% CI, -15.7% to -6.4%).
- Effect was highest for drugs that cost > $106.50 per 30-day supply (-38.9%; -47.6% to -28.7%).
- Limitations include:
- Generalizability: single academic health-care system
- RTPB recommendations were generated for < 5% of prescriptions.
- Unknown effect on total out-of-pocket drug spending
The take-home message?
This study demonstrated that providing real-time feedback to prescribers about lower cost alternatives to prescribed medications led to a reduction in out-of-pocket costs for their patients. Whether an RTPB system results in improved medication adherence remains to be seen.

Yoga improves function in knee OA (but only if you actually do it).
One-Minute Telegram 60-2022-3/3
- Background: Yoga has many health benefits, but in-person classes are not universally accessible due to cost and convenience. This study set out to assess the benefit of a home-based online yoga program for reduction of symptoms in knee osteoarthritis (OA).
- Study population: adults with symptomatic knee OA
- Methods
- Two-group superiority
[RCT](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Z1e0580d334bc09a6165af18f833e9a28)
- Unsupervised online yoga program for 12 weeks (n = 107) vs. control (n = 105)
- Outcomes assessed at 12 and 24 weeks
- Both groups received online OA education.
- Two-group superiority
- Main results
- At 12 weeks, the yoga group had improved function but not improved knee pain with walking compared to the control group (primary outcome).
- Self-reported participation among yoga group participants:
- During 12 week intervention: mean of 2.5 (±0.7) sessions per week
- After 12 week intervention: mean of 2.5 (±6.4) sessions total
- There were no serious
[adverse events](/de/wissen/Qualitätsmanagement#Z4819640973dcff73dbf583f1b61eae1c).
- Effects were not sustained at 24 weeks.
- Limitations include: lack of blinding
The take-home message?
This study demonstrated that an unsupervised online yoga program improves function for patients with symptomatic OA of the knee, but those benefits are lost if the practice is not maintained. Whether ongoing yoga practice can maintain these benefits remains to be seen.

Edition 59 - September 24, 2022
Sugar free is not risk free
One-Minute Telegram 29-2022-1/3
- Background: This study set out to investigate whether artificial sweeteners have a negative effect on cardiovascular health.
- Study population
- 103,388 adults (mean age 42.2±14.4, 79.8% female), recruited via the Étude NutriNet-Santé website
- Individuals with cardiovascular disease (CVD) or preexisting diabetes were excluded.
- Methods
- Main results
- 37.1% of participants consumed artificial sweeteners.
- Higher total artificial sweetener intake (independent of other CVD risk factors) was associated with an increased risk of:
- Cardiovascular disease (HR 1.09; 95% CI, 1.01–1.18)
- Cerebrovascular disease (HR 1.18; 1.06–1.31)
- Limitations include:
- Observational design: Causality cannot be established.
- Generalizability: Nearly 80% of participants were female; individuals with preexisting diabetes or CVD were excluded.
- Classification
[bias](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Za32c4b865a6b42d97c485db50e405ab0): Consumption was self-reported.
The take-home message?
With mounting evidence of the harmful health effects of added sugars, the food industry and consumers have increasingly turned to artificial sweeteners as an alternative. However, results from this prospective cohort study show that intake of artificial sweeteners is associated with higher cardiovascular disease risk, adding to the growing evidence [64] that sugar-free products are not necessarily risk-free.

Asporvapril? Ramaspastatin? Single polypill for secondary
[ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8) prevention better than usual care
One-Minute Telegram 29-2022-2/3
- Background: This study investigated if combining key medications into a single polypill affects cardiovascular outcomes and medication adherence.
- Study population: 2499 older adults (age > 75 years or > 65 years with risk factors) who had had a type 1 myocardial infarction ≤ 6 months prior to study inclusion
- Methods
- Phase 3
[RCT](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Z1e0580d334bc09a6165af18f833e9a28)with a 36-month follow-up
- Polypill (
[aspirin](/de/wissen/Thrombozytenaggregationshemmer#Z2bf6095ed24962e2237f2691a98fca66)100 mg; [ramipril](/de/wissen/RAAS-Inhibitoren#Z4cb19ed9db989ac77a27bb618fe50541)2.5, 5, or 10 mg; and [atorvastatin](/de/wissen/Lipidsenker#Zc0c8744cee387048609bafe6c953e2dd)20 or 40 mg) vs. usual care
- Primary composite outcome: cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, nonfatal ischemic stroke, or urgent revascularization
- Phase 3
- Main results
- Primary composite outcome was lower in the polypill group compared to the usual care group (9.5% vs. 12.7%; HR, 0.76; 95% CI, 0.60–0.96).
- Adherence was higher in the polypill group compared to the usual care group (70% vs. 62.7%; risk ratio, 1.13; 1.06–1.20).
- Results were consistent across prespecified subgroups (e.g., country, age, sex, health history).
-
[Adverse events](/de/wissen/Qualitätsmanagement#Z4819640973dcff73dbf583f1b61eae1c)similar between groups
- Limitations include: lack of blinding
The take-home message?
Adherence to secondary
[ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8) prevention medications is low [66] and decreases with more complex medication regimens. [67] In this [RCT](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Z1e0580d334bc09a6165af18f833e9a28), a polypill strategy was associated with a significantly lower risk of major adverse cardiovascular events and significantly better adherence than usual care, further contributing to the large body of high-level evidence favoring the polypill strategy; [68] but will this become the standard of care anytime soon?

The rhythm is gonna get you: early rhythm control in low-risk AF
One-Minute Telegram 59-2022-3/3
- Background: This study investigated whether early rhythm control may be beneficial for patients with atrial
[fibrillation](AF) who are at low risk of cardiovascular complications.
- Study population
- 54,216 patients with AF who received rhythm control (with either antiarrhythmic drugs or ablation) or rate control within 1 year of AF diagnosis
- Divided into 2 groups according to their CHA2DS2-VASc score:
- Methods
- Population-based retrospective cohort study
- Primary composite outcome: cardiovascular death, ischemic stroke, hospitalization for heart failure, or myocardial infarction
- Follow-up:
[median](/de/wissen/Angewandte_Statistik#Z7c0546fc00695bf5211ab50534e91c9b)of 3 years (IQR, 1.9–4.1 years)
- Main results
- Early rhythm control was associated with lower risk for the primary composite outcome in both the low-risk group (HR, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.66–0.98) and the high-risk group (0.86; 0.81–0.92).
- Safety outcomes did not differ between groups.
- Limitations include
- Residual
[confounding](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Zb4262971e106e4799561831435f78cd1): Data was extracted from a claims-based database.
- Generalizability: Patients treated with catheter ablation at
[baseline](/de/wissen/Kardiotokografie_(CTG)#Z2e7e2d1776c1d22f8722ebdfa4ddd293)were underrepresented.
- Residual
The take-home message?
Early rhythm control has previously been shown to be beneficial for patients with AF who are at high risk of cardiovascular complications (i.e., CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥ 2). [70] Results from this study show that early rhythm control in AF is associated with a reduced risk of cardiovascular events, even in patients with CHA2DS2-VASc score < 2. Early rhythm control should, therefore, be considered for all patients with AF.

The trip to abstinence:

One-Minute Telegram 58-2022-1/3
- Background: This study investigated whether the addition of
[psilocybin](/de/wissen/Halluzinogene_(Intoxikation_und_Abhängigkeit)#Z85f01850d4920624b07f9373073a8187)to psychotherapy improves the treatment of alcohol use disorder (AUD).
- Study population: adults with alcohol dependence and ≥ 4 heavy drinking days/week (≥ 5 drinks/day for men and ≥ 4 drinks/day for women) during the 30 days prior to screening
- Methods
- Randomized controlled trial: 95 adults aged 25–65 years (mean age 46 years; 44.2% female)
- All participants received 12 weeks of psychotherapy during the course of the study.
- Participants were randomized to receive either high-dose

Intermittent fasting effective for weight loss
One-Minute Telegram 57-2022-2/3
- Background: Intermittent fasting (i.e., the limitation of dietary intake to a restricted time window) has been proposed as a method to enhance weight loss and increase associated health benefits. Is early time-restricted eating (eTRE) more effective than a non-time-restricted eating window?
- Study population
- 90 adults with obesity
- 80% female; mean
[BMI](/de/wissen/Metabolisches_Syndrom#Z012e2e49483585b4280dc450c5c88d04)39.6 (SD 6.7); mean age 43 years (range 25–75 years)
- Methods
- Randomized controlled trial
- All participants received weight loss counseling involving energy restriction (ER).
- Randomization 1:1 for a total study duration of 14 weeks:
- ER + eTRE: 8-hour eating window from 7:00 to 15:00
- ER + control eating window (CON): self-selected ≥ 12-hour window
- Main results
- ER + eTRE compared to ER + CON
- Weight loss: -2.3 kg (95% CI, -3.7 to -0.9)
- Diastolic blood pressure: -4 mm Hg (-8 to 0)
- Fewer mood disturbances
- No significant differences in body fat, ratio of fat loss to weight loss or other cardiometabolic risk factors, food intake, physical activity, or sleep outcome
- The self-reported eating window of participants in the eTRE group was 7.6 hours compared to 12.3 hours in the CON group.
- Average eTRE adherence: 6 days per week
- ER + eTRE compared to ER + CON
- Limitations include:
- Statistical
[power](/de/wissen/Medizinische_Statistik_und_Testtheorie#Z59e31e2861112feed228cdcd9631f60e): small sample size
- Short duration: no data on sustained benefits
- Generalizability: 80% of participants were women.
- Statistical
The take-home message?
Although total caloric intake did not differ between groups, restricting eating to the first 8 hours of the day was more effective for weight loss than a ≥ 12-hour eating window. However, the clinical relevance of this finding is questionable, as the effect size was small. Larger studies are needed to further clarify the effectiveness and cardiometabolic impacts of intermittent fasting.

Edition 55 - July 30, 2022
Do weekend warriors benefit from exercise as much as those who work out more regularly?
One-Minute Telegram 55-2022-1/3 - Exercising only on the weekend - being a “weekend warrior” - is a convenient option for achieving the World Health Organization's recommended levels of moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA), but does the number of activity sessions per week impact the health benefits?
This prospective, survey-based cohort study followed 350,978 adults (mean age 41.4 years, 50.8% women, 67.8% non-Hispanic White) for a
[median](/de/wissen/Angewandte_Statistik#Z7c0546fc00695bf5211ab50534e91c9b) of 10.4 years and their data was linked to their National Death Index records.
Based on self-reported physical activity, participants were classified as either physically inactive (MVPA < 150 minutes/week) or physically active (≥ 150 minutes/week of moderate activity or ≥ 75 minutes/week of vigorous activity). The physically active group was further subdivided into a regularly active group (≥ 3 sessions/week) and a weekend warrior group (1–2 sessions/week).
Compared to the inactive group, both the regularly active group (HR, 0.85; 95% CI, 0.83–0.88) and the weekend warrior group (0.92; 0.83–1.02) had reduced all-cause mortality rates, though the reduction in the weekend warrior group was nonsignificant. However, differences in the rates of all-cause and cause-specific mortality between the regularly active and weekend warrior groups were nonsignificant.
Limitations include that activity levels were self-reported and therefore may not have accurately reflected the participants’ actual activity levels, that the number of deaths in the weekend warrior group was low, which may have limited the study’s
[power](/de/wissen/Medizinische_Statistik_und_Testtheorie#Z59e31e2861112feed228cdcd9631f60e) to detect a reduction in mortality in this group, and that residual [confounding](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Zb4262971e106e4799561831435f78cd1) cannot be ruled out.
The take-home message?
In this long-term prospective trial, all-cause mortality was lower in participants who achieved the recommended amount of MVPA compared to those who did not. Mortality rates did not differ significantly between those who exercised throughout the week and those who performed 1–2 sessions per week (“weekend warriors”).
- Title of study: Association of the “weekend warrior” and other leisure-time physical activity patterns with all-cause and cause-specific mortality: a nationwide cohort study [92]
- Authors: dos Santos M et al.
- Journal: JAMA Internal Medicine
Updated USPSTF recommendations on dietary supplements to prevent cardiovascular disease and cancer
One-Minute Telegram 55-2022-2/3 - The USPSTF has updated its 2014 recommendations on the use of
[vitamin](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Z6ff1b6359e20f0dbe35655f2aff6154c), mineral, and multivitamin supplementation for the prevention of cardiovascular disease and cancer. [1] Recommendations were based on data from 84 RCTs and 6 cohort studies that addressed the harms and benefits of supplementation.
Recommendations include:
- Beta carotene supplements should not be used for the prevention of cardiovascular disease or cancer. Beta carotene was associated with an increased risk of lung cancer in individuals at increased risk of lung cancer.
-
[Vitamin E](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Zcc3966fa2cc78ee4586d724bcc14e03d)supplements should not be used for the prevention of cardiovascular disease or cancer. [Vitamin E](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Zcc3966fa2cc78ee4586d724bcc14e03d)may be associated with an increased risk of hemorrhagic stroke.
- There is insufficient evidence to recommend for or against the use of multivitamin supplements or single- or paired-nutrient supplements (excluding beta carotene and
[vitamin E](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Zcc3966fa2cc78ee4586d724bcc14e03d)) for the prevention of cardiovascular disease or cancer.
Limitations include that these recommendations only apply to community-dwelling, nonpregnant adults with no known underlying health conditions, restricting generalizability to patient groups.
The take-home message?
After reviewing current evidence, the USPSTF reaffirmed its 2014 recommendations against the use of beta carotene and
[vitamin E](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Zcc3966fa2cc78ee4586d724bcc14e03d) supplements and again concluded that evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against other dietary supplements for the prevention of cardiovascular disease or cancer.
- Title of study:
[Vitamin](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Z6ff1b6359e20f0dbe35655f2aff6154c), mineral, and multivitamin supplementation to prevent cardiovascular disease and cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement [6]

One-Minute Telegram 55-2022-3/3 -
[Hepatitis C](/de/wissen/Hepatitis_C#Zea41d9f610b41c8bcb1377f59e4ff96b) [virus](/de/wissen/Grundlagen_der_Mikrobiologie_und_Virologie#Zef93c9a12b4d6394ec16bdd4e2ec8870) ( [HCV](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Virologie#Z2d8a26ce69ee816e9fdf5fd41592c981)) infection is a curable disease that disproportionately affects people who inject drugs (PWID), but uptake of [HCV](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Virologie#Z2d8a26ce69ee816e9fdf5fd41592c981) treatment in this population has historically been low.
This longitudinal observational study was conducted in the US from 2006 to 2019 and included a community-based cohort of 1323 former and current PWID with detectable
[HCV](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Virologie#Z2d8a26ce69ee816e9fdf5fd41592c981) [RNA](/de/wissen/Aufbau_von_DNA_und_RNA#Z7a75d43207f7f53a3a6b7a9a01d9225d) at [baseline](/de/wissen/Kardiotokografie_(CTG)#Z2e7e2d1776c1d22f8722ebdfa4ddd293). Of those, 82% were Black, 71% male, and 66% [HIV](/de/wissen/HIV-Infektion#Ze7d02f019433d2bd6e8c9164f9e84604)-negative. Liver cirrhosis was assessed by semiannual transient elastography. Mortality data was obtained from a national database.
- The proportion of participants with detectable
[HCV](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Virologie#Z2d8a26ce69ee816e9fdf5fd41592c981) [RNA](/de/wissen/Aufbau_von_DNA_und_RNA#Z7a75d43207f7f53a3a6b7a9a01d9225d)and cirrhosis declined from 100% and 15%, respectively, at the beginning of the study to 48% and 8%, respectively, at the end of the observation period.
- The
[absence](/de/wissen/Epileptische_Anfälle_und_Epilepsien#Z93dedd171a6efaddb5d27c931860ee21)of [HCV](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Virologie#Z2d8a26ce69ee816e9fdf5fd41592c981) [RNA](/de/wissen/Aufbau_von_DNA_und_RNA#Z7a75d43207f7f53a3a6b7a9a01d9225d)was significantly associated with reduced [odds](/de/wissen/Epidemiologie_und_Wahrscheinlichkeiten#Z12841ac5900343a9f0d2dffc6438260c)of cirrhosis (OR, 0.28; 95% CI, 0.17–0.45) and reduced risk of all-cause mortality (HR, 0.54; 0.38–0.77).
- Overall, 39% of participants reported receiving
[hepatitis]treatment during the observation period.
Limitations include that this study was conducted in a single city, restricting generalizability. In addition, these results may lead to overestimation of treatment uptake among the general PWID population, as participation in the study likely increased the participants’
[awareness] of their [HCV](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Virologie#Z2d8a26ce69ee816e9fdf5fd41592c981) status and the availability of treatment.
The take-home message?
In this US community-based cohort study of PWID,
[HCV](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Virologie#Z2d8a26ce69ee816e9fdf5fd41592c981) [RNA](/de/wissen/Aufbau_von_DNA_und_RNA#Z7a75d43207f7f53a3a6b7a9a01d9225d) was undetectable in more than half of the initially [HCV](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Virologie#Z2d8a26ce69ee816e9fdf5fd41592c981)-positive study participants at the end of a 13-year observation period, even though PWID have historically been uninsured or insured only with Medicaid, which may adversely affect treatment uptake. Undetectable [HCV](/de/wissen/Allgemeine_Virologie#Z2d8a26ce69ee816e9fdf5fd41592c981) [RNA](/de/wissen/Aufbau_von_DNA_und_RNA#Z7a75d43207f7f53a3a6b7a9a01d9225d) correlated with a significant reduction in the [odds](/de/wissen/Epidemiologie_und_Wahrscheinlichkeiten#Z12841ac5900343a9f0d2dffc6438260c) of cirrhosis and the risk of all-cause mortality.
- Title of study: Impact of
[hepatitis C](/de/wissen/Hepatitis_C#Zea41d9f610b41c8bcb1377f59e4ff96b)treatment uptake on cirrhosis and mortality in persons who inject drugs: a longitudinal, community-based cohort study [94]

Edition 54 - July 16, 2022
Google searches for abortion pills after SCOTUS leak
One-Minute Telegram 54-2022-1/3 - On June 24, 2022, the US Supreme Court overruled the landmark 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision, shifting determination over abortion laws to state legislatures. How this decision will affect the way individuals seek information about and access to abortion remains unclear.
This study analyzed Google searches for abortion medications (i.e., mifepristone, misoprostol) before and after the Supreme Court’s decision was leaked in May 2022. Searches for abortion medications spiked to 162% higher than expected (95% CI, 149–175%) immediately after the leak. The searches were significantly higher in states with more restrictive reproductive health care policies (according to the Women’s Policy Research ranking). [95]
Limitations include that the motivation for the searches and the demographics of searchers were not available.
The take-home message?
This study shows that searches for abortion medications spiked after the leak of the Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade reversal, raising concern about the potential for an increase in medically unsupervised abortions. Further research is needed to determine how changes in abortion laws will impact the way individuals seek and attain induced abortions.
- Title of study: Internet searches for abortion medications following the leaked Supreme Court of the United States draft ruling [96]
- Authors: Poliak A et al.
- Journal: JAMA Internal Medicine

Racial and ethnic disparities in the residency match
One-Minute Telegram 54-2022-2/3 - The US physician workforce does not reflect the demographic composition of the US. Greater diversity in the workforce may reduce health care disparities. [97][98]
This study compared the total number of applicants to the number of matched residents based on self-reported race and ethnicity in 11 competitive medical specialties. The applicants were categorized into one of three groups: Asian, White (non-Hispanic), and underrepresented in medicine (URM), which comprised African American, American Indian or Alaska Native, Hispanic, and Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander.
- In all 11 competitive specialties, the proportion of URM individuals among matched residents was significantly lower than their proportion among all applicants.
- In 2 of 11 specialties, the proportion of Asian individuals among matched residents was significantly lower than their proportion among all applicants.
- In 6 of 11 specialties, the proportion of matched White residents among matched residents was significantly higher than their proportion among all applicants.
Limitations include that changes in residency
[recruitment](/de/wissen/Audiometrische_Verfahren_in_der_HNO#Z7557366df45a5d8254c0fba4a82c9b27) practices that may have occurred since 2018 are not reflected in this analysis and that categories of race and ethnicity provided in residency applications do not adequately reflect human diversity.
The take home message?
In this study, candidates from ethnic and racial groups that are underrepresented in the US physician workforce were significantly less likely to match into competitive specialties for graduate medical education (GME) training. This underscores the need to reevaluate current GME
[recruitment](/de/wissen/Audiometrische_Verfahren_in_der_HNO#Z7557366df45a5d8254c0fba4a82c9b27) strategies to increase diversity in the health care workforce.
- Title of study: Racial and ethnic differences in resident selection in 11 specialties, 2013–2018 [99]
- Authors: Bowe S et al.
- Journal: JAMA
Should we rethink resuscitation in septic shock?
One-Minute Telegram 54-2022-3/3 - Fluid resuscitation is a cornerstone of the treatment for septic shock, as is reflected in the 2021 Surviving
[Sepsis](/de/wissen/Sepsis#Za8342184d7234f30c85377d399badd38) Guidelines. However, recent observational studies suggest that fluid overload may contribute to higher [sepsis](/de/wissen/Sepsis#Za8342184d7234f30c85377d399badd38)-related mortality, even though the overall quality of evidence is low. [100][101][102]
In this multinational study, patients treated for septic shock in an ICU who had already received at least 1 L of intravenous fluids (
[IVF](/de/wissen/Sterilität,_Infertilität_und_Impotenz#Z28cfbff24bb8492ec860a3ae467441ab)) were randomized within 12 hours of septic shock onset to a restrictive-fluid group (n = 770; [median](/de/wissen/Angewandte_Statistik#Z7c0546fc00695bf5211ab50534e91c9b) [IVF](/de/wissen/Sterilität,_Infertilität_und_Impotenz#Z28cfbff24bb8492ec860a3ae467441ab) = 1798 mL), with additional [IVF](/de/wissen/Sterilität,_Infertilität_und_Impotenz#Z28cfbff24bb8492ec860a3ae467441ab) given only if patients met strict predetermined clinical indications, and a standard-fluid group (n = 784; [median](/de/wissen/Angewandte_Statistik#Z7c0546fc00695bf5211ab50534e91c9b) [IVF](/de/wissen/Sterilität,_Infertilität_und_Impotenz#Z28cfbff24bb8492ec860a3ae467441ab) = 3811 mL), in which more liberal use of additional [IVF](/de/wissen/Sterilität,_Infertilität_und_Impotenz#Z28cfbff24bb8492ec860a3ae467441ab) was permitted.
The primary outcome was 90-day mortality.
- Restrictive-fluid group: 42.3%
- Standard-fluid group: 42.1%
- Adjusted absolute difference: 0.1% (95% CI, - 4.7–4.9)
At 90 days, there was no difference in serious
[adverse events](/de/wissen/Qualitätsmanagement#Z4819640973dcff73dbf583f1b61eae1c), survival without life support, and survival after discharge.
Limitations include that the study was not blinded, that data on cointerventions and hemodynamic factors were not collected, that the study was not powered to detect differences in subgroups, and that all study sites were exclusively in Europe, which may limit generalizability.
The take home message?
In this trial, there was no difference in survival or serious
[adverse events](/de/wissen/Qualitätsmanagement#Z4819640973dcff73dbf583f1b61eae1c) in patients treated for septic shock with a restrictive fluid strategy compared to those treated with standard fluid therapy. Further prospective research is needed to determine if a restrictive fluid strategy may nevertheless be beneficial in specific subsets of patients with septic shock.
- Title of study: Restriction of intravenous fluid in ICU patients with septic shock [103]
- Authors: Meyhoff TS et al.
- Journal: NEJM

Can
[vitamin C](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Z1f2b7d076337a086cf8032ec94b59056) reduce mortality in [sepsis](/de/wissen/Sepsis#Za8342184d7234f30c85377d399badd38)?
One-Minute Telegram 53-2022-1/3 - Acute
[vitamin C](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Z1f2b7d076337a086cf8032ec94b59056) deficiency is common in critically ill patients and may contribute to oxidative organ injury and, potentially, poor outcomes. [104] A recent meta-analysis suggested a possible reduction in mortality with adjunctive high-dose [vitamin C](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Z1f2b7d076337a086cf8032ec94b59056) in patients with [sepsis](/de/wissen/Sepsis#Za8342184d7234f30c85377d399badd38), but the treatment effects were of low certainty, emphasizing the need for further high-quality trials. [105]
This international trial included 872 patients who had been in the ICU for less than 24 hours, had a proven or suspected infection, and were receiving a
[vasopressor]. Patients were randomized to receive either high-dose [vitamin C](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Z1f2b7d076337a086cf8032ec94b59056) (50 mg/kg IV; n = 435) or [placebo] (n = 437) every 6 hours for up to 96 hours.
On day 28 of the trial, the composite of death or persistent organ dysfunction occurred in 44.5% of patients in the
[vitamin C](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Z1f2b7d076337a086cf8032ec94b59056) group and in 38.5% of patients in the [placebo] group (risk ratio, 1.21; 95% CI, 1.04—1.40).
Limitations include the lack of sufficient data and
[power](/de/wissen/Medizinische_Statistik_und_Testtheorie#Z59e31e2861112feed228cdcd9631f60e) to enable detailed subgroup analysis and that the trial was conducted in three high-income countries, and therefore the generalizability to lower-income countries may be limited.
The take-home message?
Previous research had suggested the possible benefits of high-dose
[vitamin C](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Z1f2b7d076337a086cf8032ec94b59056) in critically ill patients. However, in this trial, its use in the treatment of ICU patients with [sepsis](/de/wissen/Sepsis#Za8342184d7234f30c85377d399badd38) who were receiving [vasopressors] was associated with higher mortality and persistent organ dysfunction when compared with [placebo].
- Title of study: Intravenous
[vitamin C](/de/wissen/Vitamine#Z1f2b7d076337a086cf8032ec94b59056)in adults with [sepsis](/de/wissen/Sepsis#Za8342184d7234f30c85377d399badd38)in the intensive care unit [106]
- Authors: Lamontagne F et al.
- Journal: NEJM

How accurate are brachial blood pressure cuff devices?
One-Minute Telegram 53-2022-2/3 - Measuring blood pressure (BP) with a brachial BP cuff device is a convenient alternative to invasive aortic BP measurement, but may lack accuracy. [107]
This cross-sectional study recruited 500 patients (29% female) due to undergo a clinically indicated coronary angiography. Patients with severe aortic stenosis or atrial
[fibrillation] were excluded. BP was measured invasively at the end of angiography and noninvasively using an automated BP monitor, which provided brachial cuff BP and a noninvasive measure of central BP estimated from pulse waves.
Using invasive aortic systolic BP (SBP) measurements as values of reference, brachial cuff SBP was more accurate in men than in women (mean difference in men, –0.3 mm Hg; mean difference in women, –6.5 mm Hg; P < 0.001). Conversely, noninvasive measurement of central SBP (calibrated for mean arterial pressure and diastolic BP) was more accurate in women than in men.
However, 55% of the total effect of sex on brachial cuff SBP accuracy was attributable to height; the direct effect of sex on brachial cuff SBP accuracy was insignificant.
Limitations include restricted generalizability, as 94% of participants were white, 29% were female, and all participants had an indication for coronary angiography. Additionally, the trial was conducted using only a single type of device for noninvasive BP monitoring.
The take-home message?
While brachial cuff SBP measurements were found to be accurate in men, this study shows that the method was less accurate in women, mainly because of their smaller stature. Noninvasive central SBP (derived from brachial pulse waves) appeared to be the most accurate noninvasive method in women.
- Title of study: Accuracy difference of noninvasive blood pressure measurements by sex and height [108]
- Authors: Abbaoui Y et al.
- Journal: JAMA Network Open

Can
[metformin](/de/wissen/Antidiabetika#Z844473d0d0277bb5630f7ad66be085c0) and lifestyle intervention reduce cardiovascular risk in patients with impaired [glucose](/de/wissen/Kohlenhydrate#Z7444cdfd18d587802aa4ad63a0f6da57) tolerance?
One-Minute Telegram 53-2022-3/3 - Lifestyle changes and
[glucose](/de/wissen/Kohlenhydrate#Z7444cdfd18d587802aa4ad63a0f6da57) control in patients with impaired [glucose](/de/wissen/Kohlenhydrate#Z7444cdfd18d587802aa4ad63a0f6da57) tolerance result in reduced [glucose](/de/wissen/Kohlenhydrate#Z7444cdfd18d587802aa4ad63a0f6da57) levels and reduced progression to diabetes. [109] This trial addressed whether these interventions may also improve cardiovascular outcomes.
In this
[RCT](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Z1e0580d334bc09a6165af18f833e9a28), 3234 participants with impaired [glucose](/de/wissen/Kohlenhydrate#Z7444cdfd18d587802aa4ad63a0f6da57) tolerance were randomized into 1 of 3 groups: [metformin](/de/wissen/Antidiabetika#Z844473d0d0277bb5630f7ad66be085c0) 850 mg twice daily, [placebo], or intensive lifestyle intervention aiming to reduce body weight by ≥ 7%. Participants were followed for 3 years.
Subsequently, unmasked
[metformin](/de/wissen/Antidiabetika#Z844473d0d0277bb5630f7ad66be085c0) was continued in the [metformin](/de/wissen/Antidiabetika#Z844473d0d0277bb5630f7ad66be085c0) group and all participants were offered less intensive lifestyle intervention. Follow-up continued for an average of 18 years.
Although both the use of
[metformin](/de/wissen/Antidiabetika#Z844473d0d0277bb5630f7ad66be085c0) and lifestyle intervention reduced the rate of diabetes onset, they had no significant effect on the primary outcome (first occurrence of nonfatal myocardial infarction, stroke, or cardiovascular death) compared to [placebo]:
Limitations include that
[metformin](/de/wissen/Antidiabetika#Z844473d0d0277bb5630f7ad66be085c0) adherence fell over time and that lifestyle intervention was less intensive after the initial 3 years of follow up, which may have affected the results.
The take-home message?
In this trial with a total follow-up period of 21 years, neither the use of
[metformin](/de/wissen/Antidiabetika#Z844473d0d0277bb5630f7ad66be085c0) nor lifestyle intervention lead to a reduction in myocardial infarction, stroke, or cardiovascular death in patients with impaired [glucose](/de/wissen/Kohlenhydrate#Z7444cdfd18d587802aa4ad63a0f6da57) tolerance when compared with [placebo].
- Title of study: Effects of long-term
[metformin](/de/wissen/Antidiabetika#Z844473d0d0277bb5630f7ad66be085c0)and lifestyle interventions on cardiovascular events in the diabetes prevention program and its outcome study [110]

Edition 52 - June 18, 2022
Mistreatment and discrimination contribute to physician
[burnout](/de/wissen/Unipolare_Depression#Zb41ceebc50587ff5a2f360f3ca255f70).
One-Minute Telegram 52-2022-1/3 - Physician
[burnout](/de/wissen/Unipolare_Depression#Zb41ceebc50587ff5a2f360f3ca255f70), defined as emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and a feeling of low personal accomplishment, is a common phenomenon. It has a negative impact on physicians’ well-being and may also affect patient care. Mistreatment and discrimination of physicians by patients or their relatives may be factors contributing to the development of [burnout](/de/wissen/Unipolare_Depression#Zb41ceebc50587ff5a2f360f3ca255f70). [111][112][113][114]
In this cross-sectional study utilizing a national survey, 6512 US physicians reported mistreatment and discriminatory behaviors by patients, their families, and visitors in the preceding year with the following frequencies:
- Racially or ethnically offensive remarks: 29.4%
- Offensive sexist remarks: 28.7%
- Unwanted sexual advances: 20.5%
- Refusal to allow them to provide care because of the physician’s personal attributes: 21.6%
Female and non-White physicians were significantly more likely to report mistreatment or discrimination. The experience of mistreatment or discrimination was independently associated with higher
[odds](/de/wissen/Epidemiologie_und_Wahrscheinlichkeiten#Z12841ac5900343a9f0d2dffc6438260c) of [burnout](/de/wissen/Unipolare_Depression#Zb41ceebc50587ff5a2f360f3ca255f70).
Limitations include the potential for recall and response
[bias](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Za32c4b865a6b42d97c485db50e405ab0) and that causality and the direction of the observed associations could not be determined in this survey-based cross-sectional study.
The take-home message?
This survey-based study found that mistreatment and discrimination of physicians by patients and their relatives was common and disproportionately directed at female and non-White physicians. The experience of mistreatment and discrimination were independently associated with physician
[burnout](/de/wissen/Unipolare_Depression#Zb41ceebc50587ff5a2f360f3ca255f70).
- Title of study: Physicians’ experiences with mistreatment and discrimination by patients, families, and visitors and association with
[burnout](/de/wissen/Unipolare_Depression#Zb41ceebc50587ff5a2f360f3ca255f70)[115]
- Authors: Dyrbye LN et al.
- Journal: JAMA Network Open

Does tranexamic
[acid](/de/wissen/Säure-Basen-Haushalt#Zb05ef5c16afed1435f1625918811375f) reduce perioperative morbidity in noncardiac surgery?
One-Minute Telegram 52-2022-2/3 -Tranexamic
[acid](/de/wissen/Säure-Basen-Haushalt#Zb05ef5c16afed1435f1625918811375f) (TXA), an antifibrinolytic drug, has been shown to reduce perioperative bleeding in procedures associated with high blood loss, including cardiac surgery and cesarean section. Whether prophylactic TXA can safely reduce perioperative bleeding associated with other surgical procedures remains unclear. [116][117]
In this non-inferiority trial, patients at risk for bleeding and cardiovascular events who were scheduled for noncardiac surgery were randomly assigned to receive a 1-g intravenous bolus of TXA (n = 4757) or
[placebo] (n = 4778) at the start and end of surgery.
Primary outcomes:
- Composite bleeding outcome (life-threatening bleeding, major bleeding, bleeding into a critical organ): Patients in the TXA group had a lower incidence (9.1%) at 30 days compared to those in the
[placebo]group (11.7%; HR, 0.76; 95% CI, 0.67–0.87).
- Primary safety outcome (composite of myocardial injury, non-hemorrhagic stroke, arterial thrombosis, symptomatic venous thromboembolism): Predetermined criteria for noninferiority were not met at 30 days (TXA vs.
[placebo]group HR 1.02; 95% CI, 0.92–1.14).
Limitations include that the study was terminated for financial reasons before
[recruitment](/de/wissen/Audiometrische_Verfahren_in_der_HNO#Z7557366df45a5d8254c0fba4a82c9b27) was completed and that the ability to identify perioperative thrombotic complications (a potential adverse effect of TXA use) was limited.
The take-home message?
Prophylactic tranexamic
[acid](/de/wissen/Säure-Basen-Haushalt#Zb05ef5c16afed1435f1625918811375f) for noncardiac surgery in patients at risk for bleeding and adverse cardiac events reduced blood loss and critical bleeding events but did not meet noninferiority criteria for cardiovascular safety.
- Title of study: Tranexamic
[acid](/de/wissen/Säure-Basen-Haushalt#Zb05ef5c16afed1435f1625918811375f)in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery [118]
- Authors: Devereaux PJ et al.
- Journal: NEJM

Does sweetening coffee reduce its positive impact on mortality?
One-Minute Telegram 52-2022-3/3 - Moderate coffee consumption has been associated with reduced mortality, but whether adding a sweetener influences this association has not been investigated. [119]
This prospective cohort study from the UK included a total of 171,616 participants. Self-reported coffee consumption was assessed at
[baseline](/de/wissen/Kardiotokografie_(CTG)#Z2e7e2d1776c1d22f8722ebdfa4ddd293) and outcomes were evaluated over a [median](/de/wissen/Angewandte_Statistik#Z7c0546fc00695bf5211ab50534e91c9b) follow-up of 7.0 years.
Participants who drank unsweetened coffee had a lower risk of all-cause mortality compared to the coffee abstainers. The association was U-shaped with the lowest risk of mortality in consumers of 2.5–4.5 drinks/day. Those who sweetened their coffee with sugar had a similar U-shaped association with reduced mortality, albeit with non-significant results at low (< 1.5 cups) and high (> 3.5 cups) daily coffee consumption. Use of artificial sweeteners was not consistently associated with reduced mortality. These results were independent of the type of coffee (instant, ground, decaffeinated) and important confounders, such as lifestyle factors.
Limitations include the possibility of unassessed residual confounders, the reliance on self-reported data potentially leading to misclassification, and that exposure, which was assessed at
[baseline](/de/wissen/Kardiotokografie_(CTG)#Z2e7e2d1776c1d22f8722ebdfa4ddd293) only, may not reflect actual exposure over time. Also, the number of participants using an artificial sweetener in coffee was relatively low, diminishing the [power](/de/wissen/Medizinische_Statistik_und_Testtheorie#Z59e31e2861112feed228cdcd9631f60e) to detect an association.
The take-home message?
This observational study contributes to the growing body of evidence that moderate coffee consumption is associated with a decreased overall mortality. This effect persisted with the use of sugar but not with the use of artificial sweeteners.
- Title of study: Association of sugar-sweetened, artificially sweetened, and unsweetened coffee consumption with all-cause and cause-specific mortality [120]
- Authors: Liu D et al.
- Journal: Annals of Internal Medicine

Is all chest pain created equal?
One-Minute Telegram 51-2022-1/3 - People of color and women have worse outcomes for acute myocardial infarction (AMI) than White adults and men, respectively. [121] Whether those disparities are related to differences in
[triage] and emergency department (ED) care is unclear.
This study analyzed data from the
[CDC]’s National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NHAMCS) on 4152 adults aged 18–55 with a history of ED visits for chest pain. Admission to hospital, wait times, and care received by adults in the ED were compared for women (56.8%) versus men and people of color (34.9%, of whom 89% were non-Hispanic Black) versus White individuals.
- Women experienced longer wait times prior to provider evaluation than men (48.1 mins vs. 37.2 mins, p < 0.001)
- Men were more likely than women to be:
- Seen by a provider at any given time (HR, 1.15; 95% CI, 1.05–1.26)
- Admitted to the hospital (17.9% vs. 12.4%; AOR, 1.40; 1.08–1.81)
- People of color experienced longer wait times prior to provider evaluation than White individuals.
- Women: 57.8 mins vs. 42.7 mins (p = 0.006)
- Men: 44.0 mins vs 34.0 mins (p = 0.006)
- People of color were less likely than White individuals to be seen by a provider (HR, 0.82; 0.73–0.93)
Limitations include that the authors only considered visits for chest pain, ignoring other presenting symptoms of AMI; the absolute number of AMIs was small; and there was limited data on non-Black people of color.
The take-home message?
This study demonstrated that women and people of color experience longer ED wait times and are less likely to be seen by a provider when presenting with chest pain than men and White individuals, respectively. Further study is needed to determine how these findings correlate with the worse outcomes in these groups for AMI.
- Title of study: Sex and race differences in the evaluation and treatment of young adults presenting to the emergency department with chest pain [122]
- Authors: Banco D et al.
- Journal: JAHA

Does the
[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7) vaccine reduce long COVID symptoms?
One-Minute Telegram 51-2022-2/3 - Long COVID can severely impact quality of life, but no effective treatments exist at this time. While evidence suggests that long COVID occurs less frequently in people who were vaccinated before infection, [123] the question of whether vaccination after infection can alter the course of long COVID remains unclear.
This observational cohort study included data on 28,356 individuals aged 18–69 years who had participated in the UK Office for National Statistics
[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7) Infection Survey and had received at least one dose of a [COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7) vaccine after infection. Activity-limiting long COVID was reported by 4747 individuals (16.7%). Long COVID symptom trajectories were estimated before and after vaccination.
The
[odds](/de/wissen/Epidemiologie_und_Wahrscheinlichkeiten#Z12841ac5900343a9f0d2dffc6438260c) of activity-limiting long COVID after vaccination and prior to vaccination were:
- First dose: OR, 0.877 (95% CI, 0.805–0.955)
- Second dose: OR, 0.909 (0.844–0.979)
Limitations include the observational design of the study and that the presence of long COVID was determined by survey reporting alone.
The take-home message?
This study demonstrated an association between vaccination after
[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7) and reduction in long COVID symptoms. While an observational study cannot prove causality between [COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7) vaccination and reduction in long COVID symptoms, it adds to the robust body of evidence for the benefits of vaccination against [COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7) even following infection.
- Title of study: Trajectory of long COVID symptoms after
[COVID-19](/de/wissen/COVID-19#Z133b5d6becb618171a9722fa816a56d7)vaccination: community based cohort study [124]
- Authors: Ayoubkhani D et al.
- Journal: BMJ

Are
[glucocorticoids](/de/wissen/Glucocorticoide#Z927c067ed977050973f887ebb7bbd151) a safe and effective treatment for [IgA](/de/wissen/Spezifisches_Immunsystem#Z19d82223ef9a0aaa29370a30dba188fb) nephropathy?
One-Minute Telegram 51-2022-3/3 - While immunomodulators are commonly used to treat
[IgA](/de/wissen/Spezifisches_Immunsystem#Z19d82223ef9a0aaa29370a30dba188fb) nephropathy, questions regarding the safety and [efficacy](/de/wissen/Patientenversorgung_und_Gesundheitssystem#Z9c24089e9b15284c931c20e196ceb36f) of immunosuppression remain. [125]
In this international, double-blind randomized controlled trial, 503 adults with biopsy-proven
[IgA](/de/wissen/Spezifisches_Immunsystem#Z19d82223ef9a0aaa29370a30dba188fb) nephropathy, > 1 g/day proteinuria, and an [eGFR] 20–120 mL/min/1.73 m2 were randomized 1:1 after ≥ 3 months of optimal care to receive methylprednisolone (n = 257) or [placebo] (n = 246). The initial cohort of patients in the methylprednisolone group (n = 136) received a dose of 0.6–0.8 mg/kg/day (max. dose 48 mg/day) for 2 months followed by a 6–8 month taper. The study was temporarily halted due to concerns about serious infections among participants in the methylprednisolone group. Subsequently, a reduced-dose cohort was enrolled (0.4 mg/kg/day, max. dose = 32 mg/day; n = 121). Patient follow-up continued for a minimum of 2 years.
Composite primary outcome
Annual event rate of 40% decline in
[eGFR], end-stage [renal](/de/wissen/Niere#Zec9db35c8000414a143d6d13865e492f) disease, and death due to kidney failure
- Methyprednisolone: 7.3 (95% CI, 5.7–9.4)
-
[Placebo]: 12.1 (9.7–15.1)
- HR, 0.53 (0.39–0.72)
- Full dose: HR, 0.58 (0.41–0.81)
- Reduced dose: HR, 0.27 (0.11–0.65)
Secondary outcomes
Compared to the
[placebo] group, treatment-group participants experienced:
- Slower rates of decline in
[eGFR]
- Lower rates of kidney failure requiring dialysis or transplant
- Unsustained reduction in proteinuria (in g/day)
- No difference in mortality
Serious
[adverse events](/de/wissen/Qualitätsmanagement#Z4819640973dcff73dbf583f1b61eae1c) were higher in the methylprednisolone group than in the [placebo] group, especially in the participants with the higher dose protocol.
Limitations include that the trial was paused, that the protocol was modified due to
[adverse events](/de/wissen/Qualitätsmanagement#Z4819640973dcff73dbf583f1b61eae1c), and that the majority of participants came from a single country (China).
The take-home message?
In this
[RCT](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Z1e0580d334bc09a6165af18f833e9a28) of individuals with [IgA](/de/wissen/Spezifisches_Immunsystem#Z19d82223ef9a0aaa29370a30dba188fb) nephropathy, the use of methylprednisolone reduced the composite outcome of reduced [eGFR], end-stage [renal](/de/wissen/Niere#Zec9db35c8000414a143d6d13865e492f) disease, and kidney disease-related death but was associated with an increased risk of serious [adverse events](/de/wissen/Qualitätsmanagement#Z4819640973dcff73dbf583f1b61eae1c). The 2021 [KDIGO] guideline urges extreme caution in the use of [glucocorticoids](/de/wissen/Glucocorticoide#Z927c067ed977050973f887ebb7bbd151) in [IgA](/de/wissen/Spezifisches_Immunsystem#Z19d82223ef9a0aaa29370a30dba188fb) nephropathy. [126]
- Title of study: Effect of
[oral]methylprednisolone on decline in kidney function or kidney failure in patients with [IgA](/de/wissen/Spezifisches_Immunsystem#Z19d82223ef9a0aaa29370a30dba188fb)nephropathy: The TESTING randomized clinical trial

Edition 50 - May 21, 2022
The
[aspirin](/de/wissen/Thrombozytenaggregationshemmer#Z2bf6095ed24962e2237f2691a98fca66) debate rages on: 2022 USPSTF updated recommendations
One-Minute Telegram 50-2022-1/3 - The USPSTF has updated its 2016 recommendations after commissioning a systematic review and microsimulation of outcomes on hypothetical cohorts (stratified by age, sex, and CVD risk level) to determine the benefits and harms of
[aspirin](/de/wissen/Thrombozytenaggregationshemmer#Z2bf6095ed24962e2237f2691a98fca66) ( [ASA]) use for the primary prevention of [atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8) ( [ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)) and colorectal cancer ( [CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7)). [127]
Cardiovascular disease: Outcomes were based on data from 11 RCTs and 1 pilot trial (n = 134,870).
- Low-dose
[ASA]was associated with a significant decrease in major cardiovascular events, e.g., nonfatal MI and stroke (OR, 0.90; 95% CI, 0.85–0.95).
- However, low-dose
[ASA]was not significantly associated with a reduction in all-cause mortality or cardiovascular mortality.
- Low-dose
[ASA]was associated with a significant increase in major bleeding, i.e., GI bleeding, intracranial bleeding, and hemorrhagic stroke (OR, 1.44; 1.32–1.57).
USPSTF recommendation for initiation of low-dose
[ASA] to prevent [ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)
- Adults 40–59 years with a 10-year
[ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)risk ≥ 10%: low net benefit; practice shared decision-making (Grade C recommendation)
- Adults ≥ 60 years: no cardiovascular benefit and increased risk of major bleeding; do not initiate (Grade D recommendation)
- Of note, the
[ACC](/de/wissen/Medikamente_gegen_Husten_und_bronchiale_Obstruktion#Z3f6dd950678a8bcdd0077eab31629f32)/AHA recommends considering low-dose [ASA]for primary prevention of [ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)in adults 40–70 years at high risk of [ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8)and low risk of bleeding. [80]
Colorectal cancer
- There was limited
[RCT](/de/wissen/Studientypen_der_medizinischen_Forschung#Z1e0580d334bc09a6165af18f833e9a28)evidence to support an association between low-dose [ASA]and decreased [CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7)incidence (OR, 1.07; 0.92–1.24; n=4 trials) or mortality (OR, 1.36; 0.97–1.91; n=2 trials).
- Findings were highly variable depending on the duration of follow-up.
- The evidence regarding the benefit of low-dose
[ASA]in reducing [CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7)incidence or mortality was inconclusive.
The take-home message?
This 2022 USPSTF update reduces the age range and grade of recommendation for using low-dose
[ASA] in the primary prevention of [ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8). Starting low-dose [aspirin](/de/wissen/Thrombozytenaggregationshemmer#Z2bf6095ed24962e2237f2691a98fca66) is not recommended in adults ≥ 60 years. Based on evidence of a small net benefit, low-dose [ASA] may be considered on an individual basis in adults 40–59 years with a 10-year [ASCVD](/de/wissen/Atherosklerose_und_kardiovaskuläre_Prävention#Z1622eb60ccc420a80a03c7ffa7579ed8) risk ≥ 10% and a low risk of bleeding. Whether low-dose [ASA] reduces the risk of [CRC](/de/wissen/Kolorektales_Karzinom#Z101c980042ecc72a0afd58974673eed7) remains unclear.
- Title of study:
[Aspirin](/de/wissen/Thrombozytenaggregationshemmer#Z2bf6095ed24962e2237f2691a98fca66)use to prevent cardiovascular disease: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement [8]
- Authors: US Preventive Services Task Force
